abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey highly satisfactory
            project outcomes, a highly likely sustainability, and
            substantial institutional development impacts; likewise,
            both performances by the Bank and Borrower are rated highly
            satisfactory. The reasons for success in technical
            assistance (TA) and capacity building projects outline five
            factors, namely, overall country policy and institutional
            capability, country income level, strong borrower ownership
            and implementing agencies managerial capacity, use of local
            consultants, and, intensive Bank supervision, all of which
            contributed to the success of the Project. Yet, regardless
            of success, several lessons suggest the following.
            Methodologies for project design, performance monitoring and
            evaluation, suggest that even newer mechanisms for project
            management are of limited and variable operational utility,
            unless a careful, selective approach is taken in designing
            them, and using them with common sense, as part of a shared
            effort at performance improvement over the long term, where
            indicators can make an important contribution to project
            effectiveness, and capacity development. Centralized
            procurement of scientific equipment seems to have been a
            problem, however, a decentralized approach might have been
            better, particularly given the large number of institutions
            involved, and a larger allowance provided for procurement on
            the basis of shopping. Notwithstanding, the success of the
            Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) component emphasizes the
            value of designing such projects in an integrated way, to
            address all elements of the research agenda: upgrading
            facilities, procuring scientific equipment, computers and
            software, and, training personnel, with an emphasis on
            overseas training and increasing international cooperative research.
